title: Who is the best guitarist that you still don't like and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve got to say I agree with (most) everything said by the other responders. The first one I thought of when I saw the question, and one I’m surprised is mentioned as often as he is, is Eric Clapton. Eric wanted to be a King. He really wanted to be BB but he would have settled for Freddie or Albert. He never reached those levels. Eric has always bored me. “Wonderful Tonight” is MOR pablum of the worst sort. Taking any sentimentality out of it “Tears In Heaven” is not a very good song. “Lay Down Sally” is simply country music that has been done better by a thousand actual country players. “I Shot The Sheriff” was a great single but only because it’s a great song to begin with. To give him credit where it is due he did some brilliant work with Cream. How is Eric Clapton like a cup of coffee? Both are much better with Cream. “While My Guitar Gently Weeps” is a truly brilliant track but it’s The Beatles so it would be, wouldn’t it? As a solo artist? Not so much. If you count Derek And The Dominos as a solo project he has done a grand total of one truly great song, “Layla”. On which he is playing with Duane Allman who, I have read, actually came up with that incredible riff and plays a large part of the solos. But to me his worst album by far is “Me and Mr. Johnson”. One of the few things I can agree on with Clapton was his high opinion of Robert Johnson. I’ve read interviews in which he said that at one point he wouldn’t even have conversations with people who couldn’t appreciate Johnson’s work. He ALSO stated that Robert Johnson was the one artist he didn’t feel anyone (he included) could adequately cover. So of course he releases an album of Johnson covers. Old Eric had managed to suck every bit of feeling, style and groove out of the the songs and turn them into more of his “Slowhand” wanking. That album was a complete waste of plastic. But the thing that amazes me most about Clapton is that he somehow managed to get the reputation as “GOD” while Peter Green roamed the Earth. Green arguably didn’t have the technical chops of Clapton but he had the feeling. And in Blues, “Feeling” is the most important part! Want proof? Put on “Me and Mr. Johnson” then follow it up with Green’s “Robert Johnson Songbook” which came out six years prior to Clapton’s album. Worlds apart. Blues should be about spirit, soul and getting down to the grit of the human experience on a personal level. Clapton not only lacked that but seemed incapable of even understanding how it should relate. Technically he’s very proficient and well loved. But he just leaves me cold.

Great guitar players like Steve Vai and Joe Satriani, Yngie Malmsteen and the like are very technically capable. But that doesn’t necessarily translate into “creative” when it comes writing meaningful songs. You see, the song is the thing. Malmsteen writes these opuses, and while they are impressive, they are not inspiring, at least not to me. Listening to his early stuff I found myself getting ear fatigue because he just didn’t stop. No pauses, no breaks, just an endless stream of notes. I understood what he was doing, but I found it to be just so much “talking without saying anything” meaningful. Steve Vai is unquestionably great. But every time I hear him play, he takes beautiful things and then starts throwing all this technique into the mix, subsequently destroying the beautiful thing he was creating. Oy. Joe Satriani is also a great player. When I first listened to “Surfing With The Alien” album, all I could hear was technique. I found the album to be weak in substantive writing, but strong on demonstrating all his technique - as if it was an audition tape. When I listen to a band, I want to hear music that actually touches me emotionally, even spiritually, in a way I can relate to as a listener - not just a musician. I know what all the musicians are doing (being multi-instrumental), and appreciate that. But without substance, a reason for the song to exist, I find a lot of music by “virtuoso” players to be quite dry and empty of the things that matter to most people when they listen to music. When great players come together and pay attention to substance, creating music that means something to people apart from the band, just regular people - who are the majority of listeners - then you are applying your talents in a way that will have staying power. How many of these virtuoso players will still be remembered in 100 years? I guarantee less than one tenth of one percent. People want to be moved. People like Satch and Vai and Malmsteen don’t do this as a rule. Guitar players want to be blown away. People like Satch and Vai and Malmsteen do this with most everything they produce. Speaking as a musician, I prefer to be moved, not blown away. Actually, if your music moves me, I am blown away at the beauty of the composition. And that means technique is not always going to accomplish this as much as a well crafted tune written by someone with less ability, technically. One musician’s opinion.
